facts.text: Badrinarayan and Lakshminarayan were two brothers; Badrinarayan (elder) carried on business at Raipur, Lakshminarayan (younger) at ancestral village Tirora.
Lakshminarayan's first wife died in 1919 leaving a son and daughter; son died after 1922 marriage to Mst. Chaltibai; only child left was daughter Mst. Jamnabai married to Chotteylal.
Lakshminarayan died on January 6, 1936, of heart disease, leaving estate in schs. B, C, D valued at Rs. 30,000.
Appellant Kishori Lal (defendant No. 2), youngest of five sons of Badrinarayan (defendant No. 1), claimed adoption by Lakshminarayan in Jyestha (May-June) 1935, aged 13 years.

After alleged adoption, Kishori Lal resided with Lakshminarayan, performed obsequies, placed on gaddi, turban tied; on 13th day (tervi), taken in lap by Chaltibai from Badrinarayan with consent of relations.

Chaltibai (respondent, plaintiff) denied adoption and treatment as adopted son; illiterate pardanashin woman, reposed confidence in Badrinarayan who managed estate, accounts, court work; signed papers without understanding, sometimes blank.
Disputes led to proceedings under ss.107/145 CrPC; receiver appointed; Magistrate on May 19, 1947, directed civil suit; appellant's revision unsuccessful.
In criminal case, appellant asserted adoption six months prior to death; respondent denied.
Suit by Chaltibai for declaration sch. B,C properties hers as heir, possession of sch. D.

Trial court (Additional District Judge, Bhandara, July 25, 1951) framed issues including: valid adoption in Jyestha 1935? Valid per law? Plaintiff recognized and treated as son? Dismissed suit: adoption proved, but no estoppel.
Nagpur High Court (Sept 28, 1953) reversed: no factum of adoption, no estoppel; allowed appeal.

Adoption story: Lakshminarayan asked Badrinarayan for son; at Tirora house, Jyestha 1935; Lakshminarayan put tilak, tied turban; pansupari distributed; no invitations, no publicity, no priest, no feast, no photo, no presents; Chaltibai not present, later put in her lap.
No accounts produced for adoption expenses or travel; parties maintain detailed accounts.
After adoption, Kishori Lal went back to Raipur school; returned on death day; school certificate: student Tirora June 22, 1936 - June 30, 1937 as son of Badrinarayan.
Sale deed Jan 24, 1938 by Chaltibai: adoption after death by her under husband's authority, family consent; witnessed by Badrinarayan.
Succession certificate application March 21, 1936 by Chaltibai as guardian mother; drafts showed Badrinarayan as guardian uncle.
Bahi entry July 21, 1944: Kishori Lal as adopted son; later entry March 2, 1947: son of Badrinarayan.
Adhikar patra May 4, 1946: referred dispute as mother and son.
Respondent performed appellant's marriage in 1942.
Partition in Badrinarayan family Oct 30, 1943: appellant no share due to adoption.
Mutation April 8, 1936: in favour of respondent for some property; jamabandi: appellant under guardianship of Chaltibai or Badrinarayan.

legal_issues.text: Did the deceased Lakshminarayan validly adopt the defendant No. 2 in the bright fortnight of Jyestha (June), 1935 A. D.?
Was the adoption valid according to law?
Had the plaintiff all along recognised the adoption as valid and legal and had she been treating defendant No. 2 as Lakshminarayanâ€™s son all along? If so, result?

petitioner_arguments.text: Evidence of six witnesses (Mohanlal, Badrinarayan, Narsingdas, Shankarlal, Chattarpatti, Kishorilal) and Sobharam proves adoption in Jyestha 1935.
Doctrine of estoppel: respondent represented adoption in documents/proceedings, put appellant in possession, altered his position (transplanted to another family, deprived of natural family share).
Admissions by respondent shift burden to her to disprove adoption.
Long course of conduct (obsequies, marriage, possession, mutations) requires appraising evidence to hold adoption proved.

respondent_arguments.text: Denied adoption and any recognition/treatment as adopted son; illiterate pardanashin, signed documents without understanding at Badrinarayan's instance.

court_reasoning.text: No formal deed; oral evidence insufficient, contradictory on details/ceremonies; no accounts (suspicious); no publicity/invitations/feast/priest; parties maintain accounts but none produced.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Evidence free from suspicion required for adoption changing succession; failure to produce accounts suspicious.

court_reasoning.text: Sale deed 1938 states adoption after death by widow; contradicts lifetime adoption; no explanation.
Post-adoption, appellant returned to Raipur school as son of Badrinarayan; school records confirm.
No estoppel: both parties knew true facts (no adoption); estoppel inapplicable where truth known to both.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Documents (succession app, bahi, adhikar patra, sale deed) do not admit lifetime adoption by husband; consistent with post-death adoption.

court_reasoning.text: Conduct (obsequies, lap-taking, marriage, possession) does not prove adoption; widow dependent on husband's family; admissions carry little weight.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Estoppel does not confer status; acquiescence cannot establish disproved adoption.

court_reasoning.text: Onus irrelevant post-evidence; admissions not conclusive, mere evidence; no admission of lifetime adoption.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Circumstances explain documents/acts: lonely widow under influence.

holdings.text: Factum of adoption by Lakshminarayan not established.
No estoppel against respondent as both parties conversant with true facts.
High Court correctly reversed trial court.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court upheld High Court judgment reversing trial court; held no proof of adoption by Lakshminarayan or estoppel against respondent; appellant's appeal dismissed.
outcome.relief_granted: Plaintiff (respondent) entitled to declaration and possession as heir.

key_quotes.text: As an adoption results in changing the course of succession, depriving wives and daughters of their rights... evidence... free from all suspicion of fraud and so consistent and probable as to leave no occasion for doubting its truth.

key_quotes.text: There can be no estoppel where the truth of the matter is known to both the parties.
